lesson.title: Fractions: Halves & Quarters
lesson.summary: Fractions: Halves & Quarters — summary for parents in Grade 1.

sectionsArray.md: By the end of this lesson, your child will understand the concepts of halves and quarters, recognizing and creating these fractions using everyday objects.

Fractions represent parts of a whole. In this lesson, we will focus on two simple fractions: halves (2 equal parts) and quarters (4 equal parts). Using familiar items will help your child visualize and grasp these concepts.
Understanding halves and quarters is essential for building a foundation in math. These fractions are all around us, from food to toys, making them relatable and easy to learn.

Activity: Fraction Pizza
1. Gather a round object (like a paper plate or a pizza).
2. Cut it in half. Say: "Look, we have 2 equal parts. Each part is a half!"
3. Next, cut one of those halves into 2 equal pieces. Say: "Now we have 4 equal parts. Each part is a quarter!"
4. Show the pieces and ask: "How many halves do we have? How many quarters?"
Fractions are written as \\( \frac{a}{b} \\), where \(a\) is the number of parts we have, and \(b\) is the total number of equal parts in the whole.

1. Gather a round object to cut, like a pizza or a fruit.
2. Explain what a whole is before cutting.
3. Cut the object in half and show the two pieces.
4. Discuss how each piece is a half.
5. Cut one of the halves into two more pieces to show quarters.
6. Reinforce by asking your child to identify halves and quarters in other objects around the house.
**Practice Together:** Add 8–10 scaffolded questions later. (Three starter placeholders are below.)

If your child says a half is one piece of a whole, gently correct them by saying: 'A half means we have 2 equal pieces, not just one.',If they confuse halves and quarters, remind them: 'Quarters are smaller pieces; we need 4 to make a whole.',If they struggle to identify halves, encourage them: 'Remember, we need to cut it into 2 equal parts.'
Fractions are everywhere! When you share a pizza or cut a cake, you’re using halves and quarters.
Great job exploring fractions with your child! Keep practicing, and they'll master these concepts in no time!
